summary: In Breman Asikuma, the applicant, elected Odikro of Barko, challenged the Governor-General's appointment of a committee of inquiry under the State Councils (Southern Ghana) Ordinance, c. 8 of 1952, arguing it was ultra vires as the matter had already been decided by the state council. The High Court, Eastern Judicial Division, held that appeal commissioners and inquiry committee members are public officers under the Interpretation Ordinance, and that the cause of action arose from the original proceedings before the state council in the Central Judicial Division. Thus, the application should have been filed in Cape Coast, not the Eastern Division, leading to dismissal for lack of jurisdiction. The court recommended transfer to the proper division.
citations: State Councils (Southern Ghana) Ordinance, c. 8 of 1952, s. 5
Supreme Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, Order 5, r. 1(b)
rationaleHighlights: Appeal commissioners and inquiry committee members are public officers under the Interpretation Ordinance.
The cause of action arose from the original state council proceedings, not the Governor-General's appointment.
The Governor-General's appointment had substantive legal effect, not merely formal.
Application should have been filed in the Central Judicial Division (Cape Coast).
Writ of prohibition dismissed on procedural grounds.
Court recommended transfer under Order 5, r. 1(f).
Governor-General's role distinguished from ministerial respondents.
